# Repository Guidelines

## Project Structure & Module Organization
- `_bmad/core/` holds shared workflow engines, resources, and core agents.
- `_bmad/bmm/` contains the BMM module: agents, workflows, templates, and test architecture guidance.
- `_bmad/_config/` stores manifests and IDE/agent configuration files (YAML/CSV).
- Most assets are Markdown, YAML, or CSV templates used by workflows rather than executable source code.

## Build, Test, and Development Commands
- No build or runtime commands are defined in this repository.
- There is no automated test runner configured; validation is typically manual review of templates and workflows.

## Coding Style & Naming Conventions
- Use 2-space indentation for YAML files (see `_bmad/_config/manifest.yaml`).
- Keep Markdown concise with clear headings and bullet lists; prefer kebab-case for new file names (e.g., `workflow-status-template.yaml`).
- Update related manifests when adding or renaming workflow files (see `_bmad/_config/*.csv`).

## Testing Guidelines
- Test artifacts live under `_bmad/bmm/testarch/` as reference material; there is no executable test suite.
- When changing workflows or templates, validate by opening the files and checking formatting, links, and referenced paths.

## Commit & Pull Request Guidelines
- Commit message conventions are not defined (no Git history in this workspace).
- For PRs, include a short summary of the workflow/module impacted, list updated paths, and link any related issue or request.

## Agent-Specific Notes
- This repository is a template and workflow library; keep changes minimal and focused on documentation or workflow correctness.
- Prefer reusing existing templates and standards in `_bmad/bmm/data/` and `_bmad/bmm/workflows/` instead of introducing new formats.


## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /home/vlad/Source/TenantSaas/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /home/vlad/Source/TenantSaas/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

# BMM Project Scale Levels - Source of Truth
# Reference: /_bmad/bmm/README.md lines 77-85

levels:
  0:
    name: "Level 0"
    title: "Single Atomic Change"
    stories: "1 story"
    description: "Bug fix, tiny feature, one small change"
    documentation: "Minimal - tech spec only"
    architecture: false

  1:
    name: "Level 1"
    title: "Small Feature"
    stories: "1-10 stories"
    description: "Small coherent feature, minimal documentation"
    documentation: "Tech spec"
    architecture: false

  2:
    name: "Level 2"
    title: "Medium Project"
    stories: "5-15 stories"
    description: "Multiple features, focused PRD"
    documentation: "PRD + optional tech spec"
    architecture: false

  3:
    name: "Level 3"
    title: "Complex System"
    stories: "12-40 stories"
    description: "Subsystems, integrations, full architecture"
    documentation: "PRD + architecture + JIT tech specs"
    architecture: true

  4:
    name: "Level 4"
    title: "Enterprise Scale"
    stories: "40+ stories"
    description: "Multiple products, enterprise architecture"
    documentation: "PRD + architecture + JIT tech specs"
    architecture: true

# Quick detection hints for workflow-init
detection_hints:
  keywords:
    level_0: ["fix", "bug", "typo", "small change", "quick update", "patch"]
    level_1: ["simple", "basic", "small feature", "add", "minor"]
    level_2: ["dashboard", "several features", "admin panel", "medium"]
    level_3: ["platform", "integration", "complex", "system", "architecture"]
    level_4: ["enterprise", "multi-tenant", "multiple products", "ecosystem", "scale"]

  story_counts:
    level_0: [1, 1]
    level_1: [1, 10]
    level_2: [5, 15]
    level_3: [12, 40]
    level_4: [40, 999]

# Repository Guidelines

## Project Structure & Module Organization
- `_bmad/core/` holds shared workflow engines, resources, and core agents.
- `_bmad/bmm/` contains the BMM module: agents, workflows, templates, and test architecture guidance.
- `_bmad/_config/` stores manifests and IDE/agent configuration files (YAML/CSV).

## Build, Test, and Development Commands
- No build or runtime commands are defined in this repository.
- There is no automated test runner configured; validation is typically manual review of templates and workflows.

## Coding Style & Naming Conventions
- Use 2-space indentation for YAML files (see `_bmad/_config/manifest.yaml`).
- Keep Markdown concise with clear headings and bullet lists; prefer kebab-case for new file names (e.g., `workflow-status-template.yaml`).
- Update related manifests when adding or renaming workflow files (see `_bmad/_config/*.csv`).

## Testing Guidelines
- Test artifacts live under `_bmad/bmm/testarch/` as reference material; there is no executable test suite.
- When changing workflows or templates, validate by opening the files and checking formatting, links, and referenced paths.

## Commit & Pull Request Guidelines
- Commit message conventions are not defined (no Git history in this workspace).
- For PRs, include a short summary of the workflow/module impacted, list updated paths, and link any related issue or request.

## Agent-Specific Notes
- This repository is a template and workflow library; keep changes minimal and focused on documentation or workflow correctness.

## Skills

- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):

payload.message:
Understood, and thanks for pushing on clarity.

To finalize the path, I just need the **project level** (0â€“4). Quick guide:

- 2 = medium project (5â€“15 stories)
- 3 = complex system (12â€“40 stories)
- 4 = enterprise scale (40+ stories)

content.text:
Understood, and thanks for pushing on clarity.

To finalize the path, I just need the **project level** (0â€“4). Quick guide:

- 2 = medium project (5â€“15 stories)
- 3 = complex system (12â€“40 stories)
- 4 = enterprise scale (40+ stories)

Which level should I record?

Use **Level 3 â€” complex system (12â€“40 stories)**.

Reasoning, grounded in what youâ€™ve defined (not in features):

* You are not building a starter template or a single library (that would be Level 2).
* You *are* defining:

  * a formal scope & capability model,
  * explicit invariants and guarantees,
  * deterministic enforcement points,
  * privilege transitions with governance semantics,
  * proof via contract tests and evidence,
  * a trust-first lifecycle that applies across requests, jobs, and incidents.

Each of those themes translates into **multiple non-trivial stories** even when kept minimal:

* Scope modeling alone is several stories (definitions, transitions, failure modes).
* Enforcement at choke points is several stories (write boundary, context certainty, failure semantics).
* Proof/evidence is several stories (contract tests, audit signals, onboarding-by-failure).
* Positioning and non-goals still require explicit work to encode and protect.

At the same time, it is **not Level 4**:

* You are intentionally eliminating billing, feature flags, UI scaffolding, multi-region, and enterprise integrations.
* You are building a *trust kernel*, not a full SaaS platform.

So the honest classification is:

> **Level 3: a complex, correctness-critical system with architectural depth, but constrained scope.**

This level matches both:

* the cognitive weight of the ideas, and
* the likely story count once you decompose Themes 1â€“3 properly.

Anything lower would underestimate the effort; anything higher would imply enterprise surface area youâ€™ve explicitly rejected.

payload.user_instructions:
# Repository Guidelines

## Project Structure & Module Organization
- `_bmad/core/` holds shared workflow engines, resources, and core agents.
- `_bmad/bmm/` contains the BMM module: agents, workflows, templates, and test architecture guidance.
- `_bmad/_config/` stores manifests and IDE/agent configuration files (YAML/CSV).
- Most assets are Markdown, YAML, or CSV templates used by workflows rather than executable source code.

## Build, Test, and Development Commands
- No build or runtime commands are defined in this repository.
- There is no automated test runner configured; validation is typically manual review of templates and workflows.

## Coding Style & Naming Conventions
- Use 2-space indentation for YAML files (see `_bmad/_config/manifest.yaml`).
- Keep Markdown concise with clear headings and bullet lists; prefer kebab-case for new file names (e.g., `workflow-status-template.yaml`).
- Update related manifests when adding or renaming workflow files (see `_bmad/_config/*.csv`).

## Testing Guidelines
- Test artifacts live under `_bmad/bmm/testarch/` as reference material; there is no executable test suite.
- When changing workflows or templates, validate by opening the files and checking formatting, links, and referenced paths.

## Commit & Pull Request Guidelines
- Commit message conventions are not defined (no Git history in this workspace).
- For PRs, include a short summary of the workflow/module impacted, list updated paths, and link any related issue or request.

## Agent-Specific Notes
- This repository is a template and workflow library; keep changes minimal and focused on documentation or workflow correctness.
- Prefer reusing existing templates and standards in `_bmad/bmm/data/` and `_bmad/bmm/workflows/` instead of introducing new formats.


## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /home/vlad/Source/TenantSaas/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /home/vlad/Source/TenantSaas/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

---
name: create-product-brief
description: Create comprehensive product briefs through collaborative step-by-step discovery as creative Business Analyst working with the user as peers.
web_bundle: true
---

# Product Brief Workflow

**Goal:** Create comprehensive product briefs through collaborative step-by-step discovery as creative Business Analyst working with the user as peers.

**Your Role:** In addition to your name, communication_style, and persona, you are also a product-focused Business Analyst collaborating with an expert peer. This is a partnership, not a client-vendor relationship. You bring structured thinking and facilitation skills, while the user brings domain expertise and product vision. Work together as equals.

---

## WORKFLOW ARCHITECTURE

This uses **step-file architecture** for disciplined execution:

### Core Principles

- **Micro-file Design**: Each step is a self contained instruction file that is a part of an overall workflow that must be followed exactly
- **Just-In-Time Loading**: Only the current step file is in memory - never load future step files until told to do so
- **Sequential Enforcement**: Sequence within the step files must be completed in order, no skipping or optimization allowed
- **State Tracking**: Document progress in output file frontmatter using `stepsCompleted` array when a workflow produces a document
- **Append-Only Building**: Build documents by appending content as directed to the output file

### Step Processing Rules

1. **READ COMPLETELY**: Always read the entire step file before taking any action
2. **FOLLOW SEQUENCE**: Execute all numbered sections in order, never deviate
3. **WAIT FOR INPUT**: If a menu is presented, halt and wait for user selection
4. **CHECK CONTINUATION**: If the step has a menu with Continue as an option, only proceed to next step when user selects 'C' (Continue)
5. **SAVE STATE**: Update `stepsCompleted` in frontmatter before loading next step
6. **LOAD NEXT**: When directed, load, read entire file, then execute the next step file

### Critical Rules (NO EXCEPTIONS)

- ðŸ›‘ **NEVER** load multiple step files simultaneously
- ðŸ“– **ALWAYS** read entire step file before execution
- ðŸš« **NEVER** skip steps or optimize the sequence
- ðŸ’¾ **ALWAYS** update frontmatter of output files when writing the final output for a specific step
- ðŸŽ¯ **ALWAYS** follow the exact instructions in the step file
- â¸ï¸ **ALWAYS** halt at menus and wait for user input
- ðŸ“‹ **NEVER** create mental todo lists from future steps

---

## INITIALIZATION SEQUENCE

### 1. Configuration Loading

Load and read full config from {project-root}/_bmad/bmm/config.yaml and resolve:

- `project_name`, `output_folder`, `planning_artifacts`, `user_name`, `communication_language`, `document_output_language`, `user_skill_level`

### 2. First Step EXECUTION

Load, read the full file and then execute `{project-root}/_bmad/bmm/workflows/1-analysis/create-product-brief/steps/step-01-init.md` to begin the workflow.

- ðŸš« FORBIDDEN to load next step until user selects 'C' (Continue)

## CONTEXT BOUNDARIES:

- Focus: Workflow initialization and document setup only
- Limits: Don't assume knowledge from other steps or create content yet
- Dependencies: Configuration loaded from workflow.md initialization

## Sequence of Instructions (Do not deviate, skip, or optimize)

### 1. Check for Existing Workflow State

First, check if the output document already exists:

**Workflow State Detection:**

- Look for file `{outputFile}`
- If exists, read the complete file including frontmatter
- If not exists, this is a fresh workflow

### 2. Handle Continuation (If Document Exists)

If the document exists and has frontmatter with `stepsCompleted`:

**Continuation Protocol:**

- **STOP immediately** and load `./step-01b-continue.md`
- Do not proceed with any initialization tasks
- Let step-01b handle all continuation logic
- This is an auto-proceed situation - no user choice needed

### 3. Fresh Workflow Setup (If No Document)

If no document exists or no `stepsCompleted` in frontmatter:

#### A. Input Document Discovery

load context documents using smart discovery. Documents can be in the following locations:
- {planning_artifacts}/**
- {output_folder}/**
- {product_knowledge}/**
- docs/**

Also - when searching - documents can be a single markdown file, or a folder with an index and multiple files. For Example, if searching for `*foo*.md` and not found, also search for a folder called *foo*/index.md (which indicates sharded content)

Try to discover the following:
- Brainstorming Reports (`*brainstorming*.md`)
- Research Documents (`*research*.md`)
- Project Documentation (generally multiple documents might be found for this in the `{product_knowledge}` or `docs` folder.)
- Project Context (`**/project-context.md`)

<critical>Confirm what you have found with the user, along with asking if the user wants to provide anything else. Only after this confirmation will you proceed to follow the loading rules</critical>

**Loading Rules:**

- Load ALL discovered files completely that the user confirmed or provided (no offset/limit)
- If there is a project context, whatever is relevant should try to be biased in the remainder of this whole workflow process
- For sharded folders, load ALL files to get complete picture, using the index first to potentially know the potential of each document
- index.md is a guide to what's relevant whenever available
- Track all successfully loaded files in frontmatter `inputDocuments` array

- Proceed directly to next step after document setup and reporting

# Repository Guidelines

## Project Structure & Module Organization
- `_bmad/core/` holds shared workflow engines, resources, and core agents.
- `_bmad/bmm/` contains the BMM module: agents, workflows, templates, and test architecture guidance.
- `_bmad/_config/` stores manifests and IDE/agent configuration files (YAML/CSV).
- Most assets are Markdown, YAML, or CSV templates used by workflows rather than executable source code.

## Build, Test, and Development Commands
- No build or runtime commands are defined in this repository.
- There is no automated test runner configured; validation is typically manual review of templates and workflows.

## Coding Style & Naming Conventions
- Use 2-space indentation for YAML files (see `_bmad/_config/manifest.yaml`).
- Keep Markdown concise with clear headings and bullet lists; prefer kebab-case for new file names (e.g., `workflow-status-template.yaml`).
- Update related manifests when adding or renaming workflow files (see `_bmad/_config/*.csv`).

## Testing Guidelines
- Test artifacts live under `_bmad/bmm/testarch/` as reference material; there is no executable test suite.
- When changing workflows or templates, validate by opening the files and checking formatting, links, and referenced paths.

## Commit & Pull Request Guidelines
- Commit message conventions are not defined (no Git history in this workspace).
- For PRs, include a short summary of the workflow/module impacted, list updated paths, and link any related issue or request.

## Agent-Specific Notes
- This repository is a template and workflow library; keep changes minimal and focused on documentation or workflow correctness.
- Prefer reusing existing templates and standards in `_bmad/bmm/data/` and `_bmad/bmm/workflows/` instead of introducing new formats.

# Brainstorming Session Results

**Facilitator:** {{user_name}}
**Date:** {{date}}

## Session Overview

**Topic:** Define what the project should scaffold and how it can be meaningfully better for users.
**Goals:** Build clearer understanding of the product and its value to users.

### Context Guidance

Focus areas include user problems, feature ideas, technical approaches, UX, business value, differentiation, risks, and success metrics.

### Session Setup

We will explore scaffolding scope, user impact, and differentiators to sharpen the product definition before drafting downstream planning artifacts.

## Technique Selection

**Approach:** AI-Recommended Techniques
**Analysis Context:** Define scaffolding scope and differentiation with focus on clarifying what is being built and sharpening user value.

**Recommended Techniques:**

- **First Principles Thinking:** Strip assumptions about scaffolds to define core truths users need, establishing the baseline scope.
- **SCAMPER Method:** Systematically vary the scaffold to generate differentiated options and feature angles.
- **Role Playing:** Pressure-test ideas through stakeholder lenses to prioritize what is genuinely valuable.

**AI Rationale:** Start with fundamentals, expand the idea space methodically, then validate against real-world user perspectives.

## Technique Execution Results

**First Principles Thinking:**

- **Interactive Focus:** Core truths of multi-tenant trust, scope semantics, and enforceable guarantees.
- **Key Breakthroughs:** Trust contract as the product, scope calculus with explicit transitions, and a capability matrix to prevent privilege creep.
- **Developed Ideas:** Invariant-first scaffold, deterministic tenant context, frictionful admin elevation, dedicated reporting scope, and explicit PII gating.

## Idea Organization and Prioritization

**Thematic Organization:**

**Theme 1: Trust Invariants & Guarantees**  
Focus: What must always be true, and how guarantees are expressed.  
Ideas: Invariant-First Scaffold, Trust Contract Five, Explicit Contract Surface, Deny by Default, No Silent Fallbacks, Honest Infrastructure.

**Theme 2: Scope & Capability Model**  
Focus: Defining scope types, capabilities, and allowable transitions.  
Ideas: Capabilityâ€“Identity Separation, Scopeâ€“Operation Primitive Grid, Tenant Identity as an Operation, Host â‰  Tenant Null, Read-Only Reporting Scope, Job Scope as First-Class, Transition Gate Contracts.

**Theme 3: Enforcement & Choke Points**  
Focus: Where the system enforces invariants mechanically.  
Ideas: Tenant Certainty Gate, Choke-Point Enforcement Layer, Deterministic Tenant Context Pipeline, No Middleware-Only Enforcement, No Implicit Tenant Inference, No Tenant-Null State.

**Theme 4: Privilege & Governance**  
Focus: How power is granted, constrained, and reviewed.  
Ideas: Frictionful Privileged Scope, Reviewable Power, Privileged Path Least Convenient, No Global Admins, No Unbounded Cross-Tenant Ops, PII Access as a Dedicated Gate.

**Theme 5: Proof, Evidence & Onboarding**  
Focus: Making guarantees provable and learnable.  
Ideas: Provable Architecture, Contract Tests First, Docs from Policy, Trust from Day One, Onboard by Failure, Operational Truth, Compliance Evidence Generator.

**Theme 6: Positioning & Lifecycle Leverage**  
Focus: How the trust kernel scales across lifecycle and messaging.  
Ideas: Trust-First Kernel, Trust Foundation Trio, Tenancy as OS, Safe by Default/Usable by Design, Intentional Governance, Policy Kernel Validates Modules, Boundary-First Data Modeling, Migration Safety Net, Incident Response Safety Gear, Agent Containment Infrastructure, Trust Marketing Backed by Code, No Feature Bundling Baseline, Guardrails Over Flexibility, No Mixed-Scope Execution, No Casual Cross-Tenant Utilities, Scope Before Auth, Invariants Before Domain.

**Prioritization Results:**

- **Top Priority Ideas:** Theme 1 (Trust Invariants & Guarantees), Theme 2 (Scope & Capability Model), Theme 3 (Enforcement & Choke Points).
- **Secondary Themes:** Theme 5 (Proof, Evidence & Onboarding), Theme 4 (Privilege & Governance).
- **Positioning Focus (later):** Theme 6 (Positioning & Lifecycle Leverage).

**Action Planning:**

1. **Define Trust Invariants & Guarantees**
   - Draft the non-negotiable trust contract (what is guaranteed and what is not).
   - Establish kill criteria for features that dilute or bypass guarantees.
   - Encode the contract as a short, explicit baseline spec.

2. **Formalize Scope & Capability Model**
   - Specify scope types, allowed operations, and transition rules.
   - Build the capability matrix (scope Ã— operation) as source of truth.
   - Identify which operations require explicit elevation and audit metadata.

3. **Implement Enforcement at Choke Points**
   - Identify write/query boundaries and job execution entry points.
   - Define deterministic tenant resolution and conflict-fail rules.
   - Add contract tests that prove invariants hold at these boundaries.

## Session Summary and Insights

**Key Achievements:**

- Established a trust-first thesis with explicit non-negotiable guarantees.
- Defined a scope calculus and operation matrix for consistent governance.
- Anchored enforcement at chokepoints with provable invariants.
- Clarified prioritization that prevents feature gravity.

**Session Reflections:**

This session converged quickly on a trust-kernel identity. The strongest value is not in a feature set, but in a minimal, explicit contract enforced by scope and proven at boundaries.

# Step 2: Product Vision Discovery

## STEP GOAL:

Conduct comprehensive product vision discovery to define the core problem, solution, and unique value proposition through collaborative analysis.

## MANDATORY EXECUTION RULES (READ FIRST):

### Universal Rules:

- ðŸ›‘ NEVER generate content without user input
- ðŸ“– CRITICAL: Read the complete step file before taking any action
- ðŸ”„ CRITICAL: When loading next step with 'C', ensure entire file is read
- ðŸ“‹ YOU ARE A FACILITATOR, not a content generator
- âœ… YOU MUST ALWAYS SPEAK OUTPUT In your Agent communication style with the config `{communication_language}`

### Role Reinforcement:

- âœ… You are a product-focused Business Analyst facilitator
- âœ… If you already have been given a name, communication_style and persona, continue to use those while playing this new role
- âœ… We engage in collaborative dialogue, not command-response
- âœ… You bring structured thinking and facilitation skills, while the user brings domain expertise and product vision
- âœ… Maintain collaborative discovery tone throughout

### Step-Specific Rules:

- ðŸŽ¯ Focus only on product vision, problem, and solution discovery
- ðŸš« FORBIDDEN to generate vision without real user input and collaboration
- ðŸ’¬ Approach: Systematic discovery from problem to solution
- ðŸ“‹ COLLABORATIVE discovery, not assumption-based vision crafting

## EXECUTION PROTOCOLS:

- ðŸŽ¯ Show your analysis before taking any action
- ðŸ’¾ Generate vision content collaboratively with user
- ðŸ“– Update frontmatter `stepsCompleted: [1, 2]` before loading next step
- ðŸš« FORBIDDEN to proceed without user confirmation through menu

## CONTEXT BOUNDARIES:

- Available context: Current document and frontmatter from step 1, input documents already loaded in memory
- Focus: This will be the first content section appended to the document
- Limits: Focus on clear, compelling product vision and problem statement
- Dependencies: Document initialization from step-01 must be complete

## Sequence of Instructions (Do not deviate, skip, or optimize)

### 1. Begin Vision Discovery

**Opening Conversation:**
"As your PM peer, I'm excited to help you shape the vision for {{project_name}}. Let's start with the foundation.

**Tell me about the product you envision:**

- What core problem are you trying to solve?
- Who experiences this problem most acutely?
- What would success look like for the people you're helping?
- What excites you most about this solution?

Let's start with the problem space before we get into solutions."

### 2. Deep Problem Understanding

**Problem Discovery:**
Explore the problem from multiple angles using targeted questions:

- How do people currently solve this problem?
- What's frustrating about current solutions?
- What happens if this problem goes unsolved?
- Who feels this pain most intensely?

### 3. Current Solutions Analysis

**Competitive Landscape:**

- What solutions exist today?
- Where do they fall short?
- What gaps are they leaving open?
- Why haven't existing solutions solved this completely?

### 4. Solution Vision

**Collaborative Solution Crafting:**

- If we could solve this perfectly, what would that look like?
- What's the simplest way we could make a meaningful difference?
- What makes your approach different from what's out there?
- What would make users say 'this is exactly what I needed'?

### 5. Unique Differentiators

**Competitive Advantage:**

- What's your unfair advantage?
- What would be hard for competitors to copy?
- What insight or approach is uniquely yours?
- Why is now the right time for this solution?

### 6. Generate Executive Summary Content

**Content to Append:**
Prepare the following structure for document append:

```markdown
## Executive Summary

[Executive summary content based on conversation]

---

## Core Vision

### Problem Statement

[Problem statement content based on conversation]

### Problem Impact

[Problem impact content based on conversation]

### Why Existing Solutions Fall Short

[Analysis of existing solution gaps based on conversation]

### Proposed Solution

[Proposed solution description based on conversation]

### Key Differentiators

[Key differentiators based on conversation]
```

### 7. Present MENU OPTIONS

**Content Presentation:**
"I've drafted the executive summary and core vision based on our conversation. This captures the essence of {{project_name}} and what makes it special.

**Here's what I'll add to the document:**
[Show the complete markdown content from step 6]

**Select an Option:** [A] Advanced Elicitation [P] Party Mode [C] Continue"

#### Menu Handling Logic:

- IF A: Execute {advancedElicitationTask} with current vision content to dive deeper and refine
- IF P: Execute {partyModeWorkflow} to bring different perspectives to positioning and differentiation
- IF C: Save content to {outputFile}, update frontmatter with stepsCompleted: [1, 2], then only then load, read entire file, then execute {nextStepFile}
- IF Any other comments or queries: help user respond then [Redisplay Menu Options](#7-present-menu-options)

#### EXECUTION RULES:

- ALWAYS halt and wait for user input after presenting menu
- ONLY proceed to next step when user selects 'C'
- After other menu items execution, return to this menu with updated content
- User can chat or ask questions - always respond and then end with display again of the menu options

## CRITICAL STEP COMPLETION NOTE

ONLY WHEN [C continue option] is selected and [vision content finalized and saved to document with frontmatter updated], will you then load and read fully `{nextStepFile}` to execute and begin target user discovery.

---

## ðŸš¨ SYSTEM SUCCESS/FAILURE METRICS

### âœ… SUCCESS:

- Clear problem statement that resonates with target users
- Compelling solution vision that addresses the core problem
- Unique differentiators that provide competitive advantage
- Executive summary that captures the product essence
- A/P/C menu presented and handled correctly with proper task execution
- Content properly appended to document when C selected
- Frontmatter updated with stepsCompleted: [1, 2]

### âŒ SYSTEM FAILURE:

- Accepting vague problem statements without pushing for specificity
- Creating solution vision without fully understanding the problem
- Missing unique differentiators or competitive insights
- Generating vision without real user input and collaboration
- Not presenting standard A/P/C menu after content generation
- Appending content without user selecting 'C'
- Not updating frontmatter properly

**Master Rule:** Skipping steps, optimizing sequences, or not following exact instructions is FORBIDDEN and constitutes SYSTEM FAILURE.

As your PM peer, I'm excited to help you shape the vision for TenantSaas. Let's start with the foundation.

Tell me about the product you envision:
- What core problem are you trying to solve?
- Who experiences this problem most acutely?
- What would success look like for the people you're helping?
- What excites you most about this solution?

Letâ€™s start with the problem space before we get into solutions.

What core problem are we trying to solve?

Teams building multi-tenant SaaS systems routinely perform actions whose ownership, scope, or authority is ambiguous or implicit. That ambiguity leads to irreversible trust failures: cross-tenant data exposure, corrupted state, and unverifiable incident response. The problem is not missing features, but the absence of mechanically enforced attribution and safety guarantees in shared systems.

Who experiences this problem most acutely?

Early SaaS builders who move fast and cannot afford irreversible trust mistakes

Senior and platform engineers responsible for long-term system integrity

On-call engineers operating under stress and time pressure

Security reviewers and auditors who need verifiable guarantees, not narratives

New team members who inherit implicit rules they cannot safely infer

What would success look like for the people weâ€™re helping?

Success means confidence without constant vigilance. Unsafe actions fail immediately and clearly. Safe paths are the default. Exceptional power is explicit, constrained, and reviewable. Teams can evolve systems, handle incidents, and onboard new engineers without fear of silently violating customer trust.

What excites us most about this solution?

It reframes multi-tenant SaaS from a feature problem into a systems safety problem. By encoding trust as enforceable invariants rather than conventions, it prevents irreversible failures, scales with teams and products, and turns correctness into a property that can be proven rather than hoped for.

Treasure unearthedâ€”this is crisp and deeply grounded. Letâ€™s press on the problem from a few angles so the brief captures it with full force.

Deep problem understanding:
- How do teams *currently* solve this (or paper over it) in real systems?

content.text:
Treasure unearthedâ€”this is crisp and deeply grounded. Letâ€™s press on the problem from a few angles so the brief captures it with full force.

Deep problem understanding:
- How do teams *currently* solve this (or paper over it) in real systems?
- Whatâ€™s most frustrating or risky about those approaches?
- What happens when this problem goes unsolvedâ€”whatâ€™s the â€œpoint of no returnâ€ failure?
- Who feels the pain most intensely in practice, and why them first?

How do teams currently solve this (or paper over it)?

Most teams rely on a mix of conventions and partial safeguards:

Passing tenantId everywhere by habit and code review

Repository patterns that promise tenant scoping but donâ€™t enforce it

Middleware that sets tenant context only for HTTP requests

Admin tools, scripts, and jobs that bypass normal paths â€œtemporarilyâ€

Documentation and tribal knowledge (â€œbe careful with tenant stuffâ€)

Post-hoc detection via logs or customer reports

These approaches reduce obvious mistakes, but they are informal, uneven, and fragile.

Whatâ€™s most frustrating or risky about those approaches?

They depend on human memory and discipline, which degrades under speed, stress, and team growth

They donâ€™t cover non-happy paths (jobs, migrations, backfills, incidents)

They fail silently until damage is done

They create false confidenceâ€”systems appear safe until one path isnâ€™t

When something goes wrong, reconstruction is guesswork, not diagnosis

The risk is not frequent failureâ€”itâ€™s rare, catastrophic failure.

What happens when this problem goes unsolved?

The point of no return is the first real cross-tenant trust violation.

After that:

Customer trust is permanently damaged

Legal and compliance exposure appears

Engineering velocity drops due to fear and over-process

Systems accrete defensive complexity instead of clarity

Teams either rewrite core systems or accept ongoing risk

This is rarely a clean failure; itâ€™s a slow loss of confidence followed by a sharp incident.

Who feels the pain most intensely, and why them first?

On-call engineers â€” because they act under pressure and own the blast radius

Platform and senior engineers â€” because they inherit and are accountable for systemic risk

Founders â€” because one incident can outweigh years of progress

Security and compliance teams â€” because they must defend guarantees that arenâ€™t enforceable

They feel it first because they are closest to consequences, not abstractions.

Bottom line:
Teams donâ€™t lack awareness of the problem; they lack systems that make unsafe states impossible. Until that changes, multi-tenant SaaS safety remains probabilistic rather than guaranteed.

Exactly the kind of clarity we need. Letâ€™s map the competitive landscape so the brief can state the gap without handâ€‘waving.

Current solutions analysis:
- What solutions exist today (frameworks, libraries, patterns, vendors)?
- Where do they fall short *specifically* for your trustâ€‘invariant goals?

content.text:
Exactly the kind of clarity we need. Letâ€™s map the competitive landscape so the brief can state the gap without handâ€‘waving.

Current solutions analysis:
- What solutions exist today (frameworks, libraries, patterns, vendors)?
- Where do they fall short *specifically* for your trustâ€‘invariant goals?
- What gaps are they leaving open that you intend to close?
- Why havenâ€™t existing solutions solved this completely?

Here is a **non-hand-wavy competitive landscape**, mapped directly against the trust-invariant goals youâ€™ve defined.

---

## What solutions exist today?

### Full frameworks

* **ABP Framework / ASP.NET Boilerplate**
  Comprehensive multi-tenant frameworks with identity, permissions, modules.
* **Django (django-tenants)**
  Strong tenancy patterns at the ORM/database layer.
* **Ruby on Rails (ActsAsTenant)**
  Convention-based tenant scoping.

### Focused libraries

* **Finbuckle.MultiTenant**
  Lightweight tenant resolution and context propagation.
* Homegrown middleware + repository patterns (very common).

### Infrastructure / vendor solutions

* Auth providers (Auth0, Azure AD B2C)
* Database isolation strategies (schema-per-tenant, DB-per-tenant)
* Logging/monitoring vendors

---

## Where do they fall short for *trust-invariant* goals?

### 1. They optimize for **capabilities**, not **guarantees**

Most solutions answer *â€œHow do I support multi-tenancy?â€*, not
*â€œWhat must never be allowed to happen?â€*

* Isolation is often **conventional**, not enforced
* â€œAdminâ€ is usually a permanent role, not a scoped, auditable capability
* Background jobs, scripts, migrations are left to discipline

---

### 2. Enforcement is **partial and contextual**

* Middleware works for HTTP, not for jobs or scripts
* ORM filters protect reads, not writes
* Cross-tenant actions are technically easy, socially discouraged

This creates *safety gaps exactly where real incidents happen*.

---

### 3. Tenant attribution is **optional or implicit**

* Tenant context can be missing, inferred, or overridden
* Conflicts between tenant identifiers are often resolved silently
* â€œTenant = nullâ€ is treated as a valid state

This undermines auditability, incident response, and compliance.

---

### 4. Privilege is treated as a role, not an event

* Global admins are common
* Cross-tenant access is normalized
* Little or no structured evidence of *why* power was exercised

From a trust perspective, this is indistinguishable from no control.

---

### 5. Proof is absent

* No contract tests proving isolation invariants
* No executable trust guarantees
* Audits rely on documentation and interviews, not artifacts

Systems *appear* safe until they arenâ€™t.

---

## What gaps do these leave open?

1. **No explicit trust contract**

   * What is guaranteed vs not guaranteed is rarely stated clearly.

2. **No invariant-first design**

   * Trust rules are layered on after the fact.

3. **No universal choke points**

   * Enforcement depends on which abstraction you remembered to use.

4. **No formal scope calculus**

   * Tenant, host, admin, support, reporting scopes are informal or conflated.

5. **No built-in proof**

   * Teams cannot mechanically verify that isolation holds as the system evolves.

---

## Why havenâ€™t existing solutions solved this completely?

Because solving this problem **cuts against incentives and ergonomics**:

* Frameworks optimize for adoption and feature breadth, not safety rigidity.
* Vendors avoid friction that might slow developers down.
* Teams underestimate the cost until after their first incident.
* Guarantee-driven design requires saying â€œnoâ€ to convenience.
* Proving invariants is harder than documenting best practices.

In short:
**trust invariants are uncomfortable early and catastrophic late**, and most solutions bias toward early comfort.

---

## The gap we intend to close

Not *â€œbetter multi-tenancy featuresâ€*, but:

* **Explicit, narrow guarantees**
* **Mechanical enforcement at invariant boundaries**
* **Formal scope and privilege semantics**
* **Auditable, reviewable power**
* **Executable proof of correctness**

That gap exists precisely because it is *not* a feature checklistâ€”it is a **systems safety stance** that most tools avoid taking.

This is why TenantSaaS is not competing head-on with frameworks or vendors; it occupies a layer they deliberately leave underspecified.

Excellentâ€”this is sharp and specific. Letâ€™s lock in the solution vision and differentiators.

Solution vision:
- If we could solve this perfectly, what would it look like in practice?

content.text:
Excellentâ€”this is sharp and specific. Letâ€™s lock in the solution vision and differentiators.

Solution vision:
- If we could solve this perfectly, what would it look like in practice?
- Whatâ€™s the simplest version that still makes a meaningful difference?
- What makes your approach different from what exists?
- What would make users say â€œthis is exactly what I neededâ€?

Here is a **locked-in solution vision**, stated plainly and without implementation detail.

---

### If we could solve this perfectly, what would it look like in practice?

It would feel like trust is no longer something engineers *remember* to maintain.

Every meaningful action in the system would be unambiguously attributable, correctly scoped, and either allowed or refused by construction. Unsafe actions would not â€œmostly workâ€ or fail laterâ€”they would fail immediately, with clear reasons. Exceptional power would exist, but only as explicit, reviewable events.

In practice, teams would stop asking, *â€œDid we remember to handle the tenant correctly?â€* because the system would not let them forget.

---

### Whatâ€™s the simplest version that still makes a meaningful difference?

A minimal system that:

* Requires explicit attribution before shared-system actions
* Refuses to act when attribution is missing or ambiguous
* Enforces trust rules at a small number of unavoidable choke points
* Makes exceptional, cross-boundary actions explicit and visible

Nothing else is required to change the failure mode of a multi-tenant system from â€œsilent and catastrophicâ€ to â€œearly and contained.â€

---

### What makes our approach different from what exists?

Most existing solutions optimize for **capabilities**: how to support tenants, admins, jobs, reporting, billing.

This approach optimizes for **guarantees**:

* It defines what must *never* happen.
* It enforces those rules mechanically.
* It treats privilege as a scoped event, not a role.
* It provides proof, not guidance.

Instead of offering more features, it deliberately narrows the surface area to preserve trust under pressure.

---

### What would make users say, â€œthis is exactly what I neededâ€?

They would say it the first time the system stops them from making a dangerous mistakeâ€”especially under stress.

* When a background job fails loudly instead of corrupting data
* When an incident fix canâ€™t accidentally hit other customers
* When an auditor asks â€œhow do you enforce isolation?â€ and the answer is runnable code, not slides
* When a new hire learns the system by hitting guardrails, not by reading warnings

They would recognize it not as a productivity booster, but as **a safety net they didnâ€™t realize they were missing**â€”one that lets them move faster precisely because it removes silent risk.

---

**In short:**
The vision is not to make multi-tenant SaaS easier to build.
It is to make it **harder to build incorrectly**â€”and impossible to do so quietly.

* Requires explicit attribution before shared-system actions
* Refuses to act when attribution is missing or ambiguous
* Enforces trust rules at a small number of unavoidable choke points
* Makes exceptional, cross-boundary actions explicit and visible

Nothing else is required to change the failure mode of a multi-tenant system from â€œsilent and catastrophicâ€ to â€œearly and contained.â€

---

### What makes our approach different from what exists?

Most existing solutions optimize for **capabilities**: how to support tenants, admins, jobs, reporting, billing.

This approach optimizes for **guarantees**:

* It defines what must *never* happen.
* It enforces those rules mechanically.
* It treats privilege as a scoped event, not a role.
* It provides proof, not guidance.

Instead of offering more features, it deliberately narrows the surface area to preserve trust under pressure.

---

### What would make users say, â€œthis is exactly what I neededâ€?

They would say it the first time the system stops them from making a dangerous mistakeâ€”especially under stress.

* When a background job fails loudly instead of corrupting data
* When an incident fix canâ€™t accidentally hit other customers
* When an auditor asks â€œhow do you enforce isolation?â€ and the answer is runnable code, not slides
* When a new hire learns the system by hitting guardrails, not by reading warnings

They would recognize it not as a productivity booster, but as **a safety net they didnâ€™t realize they were missing**â€”one that lets them move faster precisely because it removes silent risk.

---

**In short:**
The vision is not to make multi-tenant SaaS easier to build.
It is to make it **harder to build incorrectly**â€”and impossible to do so quietly.

# Repository Guidelines

## Project Structure & Module Organization
- `_bmad/core/` holds shared workflow engines, resources, and core agents.
- `_bmad/bmm/` contains the BMM module: agents, workflows, templates, and test architecture guidance.
- `_bmad/_config/` stores manifests and IDE/agent configuration files (YAML/CSV).
- Most assets are Markdown, YAML, or CSV templates used by workflows rather than executable source code.

## Build, Test, and Development Commands
- No build or runtime commands are defined in this repository.
- There is no automated test runner configured; validation is typically manual review of templates and workflows.

## Coding Style & Naming Conventions
- Use 2-space indentation for YAML files (see `_bmad/_config/manifest.yaml`).
- Keep Markdown concise with clear headings and bullet lists; prefer kebab-case for new file names (e.g., `workflow-status-template.yaml`).
- Update related manifests when adding or renaming workflow files (see `_bmad/_config/*.csv`).

## Testing Guidelines
- Test artifacts live under `_bmad/bmm/testarch/` as reference material; there is no executable test suite.
- When changing workflows or templates, validate by opening the files and checking formatting, links, and referenced paths.

## Commit & Pull Request Guidelines
- Commit message conventions are not defined (no Git history in this workspace).
- For PRs, include a short summary of the workflow/module impacted, list updated paths, and link any related issue or request.

## Agent-Specific Notes
- This repository is a template and workflow library; keep changes minimal and focused on documentation or workflow correctness.
- Prefer reusing existing templates and standards in `_bmad/bmm/data/` and `_bmad/bmm/workflows/` instead of introducing new formats.


## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /home/vlad/Source/TenantSaas/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /home/vlad/Source/TenantSaas/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

Fantasticâ€”this is coherent and differentiated. Iâ€™ve drafted the Executive Summary + Core Vision based strictly on your inputs.

Hereâ€™s what Iâ€™ll add to the Product Brief:

```markdown
## Executive Summary

TenantSaas is a trustâ€‘first multiâ€‘tenant SaaS foundation. It addresses a systemic safety problem: teams routinely perform sharedâ€‘system actions with ambiguous ownership, scope, or authority, which leads to irreversible trust failures. The product encodes trust as explicit invariants, enforced at unavoidable choke points, so unsafe actions fail immediately and clearly. The goal is to make it hard to build multiâ€‘tenant systems incorrectlyâ€”and impossible to do so quietly.

---

## Core Vision

### Problem Statement

Multiâ€‘tenant SaaS systems regularly allow actions whose tenant ownership, scope, or authority is implicit or ambiguous. This ambiguity produces silent, catastrophic failuresâ€”crossâ€‘tenant exposure, corrupted state, and unverifiable incident responseâ€”because enforcement depends on human discipline rather than mechanical guarantees.

### Problem Impact

When the first crossâ€‘tenant violation occurs, trust is permanently damaged. Teams face legal and compliance exposure, velocity drops under fear, and systems accrete defensive complexity instead of clarity. Onâ€‘call engineers, senior platform owners, founders, and security reviewers bear the earliest and most intense consequences because they are closest to the blast radius.

### Why Existing Solutions Fall Short

Most frameworks and libraries optimize for multiâ€‘tenancy capabilities, not guarantees. Enforcement is partial and contextual (HTTP middleware but not jobs), tenant attribution is often optional or implicit, privilege is treated as a role rather than a scoped event, and proof is absent. This creates safety gaps exactly where incidents occur and produces false confidence until failure.

### Proposed Solution

A trustâ€‘first foundation that requires explicit attribution, refuses ambiguous actions, enforces invariants at a small set of unavoidable choke points, and makes exceptional power explicit and reviewable. The system shifts multiâ€‘tenant safety from â€œbest practicesâ€ to â€œmechanically enforced guarantees.â€

### Key Differentiators

- Guarantees over capabilities: define what must never happen, then enforce it.
- Invariantâ€‘first design with unavoidable enforcement boundaries.
- Formal scope and privilege semantics; exceptional power is explicit and auditable.
- Executable proof of correctness (e.g., contract tests), not narrative assurance.
- Deliberately narrow surface area to preserve trust under stress.
```

- [A] Advanced Elicitation
- [P] Party Mode
- [C] Continue

+- Deliberately narrow surface area to preserve trust under stress.

# Repository Guidelines

## Project Structure & Module Organization
- `_bmad/core/` holds shared workflow engines, resources, and core agents.
- `_bmad/bmm/` contains the BMM module: agents, workflows, templates, and test architecture guidance.
- `_bmad/_config/` stores manifests and IDE/agent configuration files (YAML/CSV).
- Most assets are Markdown, YAML, or CSV templates used by workflows rather than executable source code.

## Build, Test, and Development Commands
- No build or runtime commands are defined in this repository.
- There is no automated test runner configured; validation is typically manual review of templates and workflows.

## Coding Style & Naming Conventions
- Use 2-space indentation for YAML files (see `_bmad/_config/manifest.yaml`).
- Keep Markdown concise with clear headings and bullet lists; prefer kebab-case for new file names (e.g., `workflow-status-template.yaml`).
- Update related manifests when adding or renaming workflow files (see `_bmad/_config/*.csv`).

## Testing Guidelines
- Test artifacts live under `_bmad/bmm/testarch/` as reference material; there is no executable test suite.
- When changing workflows or templates, validate by opening the files and checking formatting, links, and referenced paths.

## Commit & Pull Request Guidelines
- Commit message conventions are not defined (no Git history in this workspace).
- For PRs, include a short summary of the workflow/module impacted, list updated paths, and link any related issue or request.

## Agent-Specific Notes
- This repository is a template and workflow library; keep changes minimal and focused on documentation or workflow correctness.
- Prefer reusing existing templates and standards in `_bmad/bmm/data/` and `_bmad/bmm/workflows/` instead of introducing new formats.


## Skills

Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /home/vlad/Source/TenantSaas/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.

name: 'step-03-users'
description: 'Define target users with rich personas and map their key interactions with the product'

# File References
nextStepFile: './step-04-metrics.md'
outputFile: '{planning_artifacts}/product-brief-{{project_name}}-{{date}}.md'

# Task References
advancedElicitationTask: '{project-root}/_bmad/core/workflows/advanced-elicitation/workflow.xml'
partyModeWorkflow: '{project-root}/_bmad/core/workflows/party-mode/workflow.md'
---

# Step 3: Target Users Discovery

## STEP GOAL:

Define target users with rich personas and map their key interactions with the product through collaborative user research and journey mapping.

## MANDATORY EXECUTION RULES (READ FIRST):

### Universal Rules:

- ðŸ›‘ NEVER generate content without user input
- ðŸ“– CRITICAL: Read the complete step file before taking any action
- ðŸ”„ CRITICAL: When loading next step with 'C', ensure entire file is read
- ðŸ“‹ YOU ARE A FACILITATOR, not a content generator
- âœ… YOU MUST ALWAYS SPEAK OUTPUT In your Agent communication style with the config `{communication_language}`

### Role Reinforcement:

- âœ… You are a product-focused Business Analyst facilitator
- âœ… If you already have been given a name, communication_style and persona, continue to use those while playing this new role
- âœ… We engage in collaborative dialogue, not command-response
- âœ… You bring structured thinking and facilitation skills, while the user brings domain expertise and product vision
- âœ… Maintain collaborative discovery tone throughout

### Step-Specific Rules:

- ðŸŽ¯ Focus only on defining who this product serves and how they interact with it
- ðŸš« FORBIDDEN to create generic user profiles without specific details
- ðŸ’¬ Approach: Systematic persona development with journey mapping
- ðŸ“‹ COLLABORATIVE persona development, not assumption-based user creation

## EXECUTION PROTOCOLS:

- ðŸŽ¯ Show your analysis before taking any action
- ðŸ’¾ Generate user personas and journeys collaboratively with user
- ðŸ“– Update frontmatter `stepsCompleted: [1, 2, 3]` before loading next step
- ðŸš« FORBIDDEN to proceed without user confirmation through menu

## CONTEXT BOUNDARIES:

- Available context: Current document and frontmatter from previous steps, product vision and problem already defined
- Focus: Creating vivid, actionable user personas that align with product vision
- Limits: Focus on users who directly experience the problem or benefit from the solution
- Dependencies: Product vision and problem statement from step-02 must be complete

## Sequence of Instructions (Do not deviate, skip, or optimize)

### 1. Begin User Discovery

**Opening Exploration:**
"Now that we understand what {{project_name}} does, let's define who it's for.

**User Discovery:**

- Who experiences the problem we're solving?
- Are there different types of users with different needs?
- Who gets the most value from this solution?
- Are there primary users and secondary users we should consider?

Let's start by identifying the main user groups."

### 2. Primary User Segment Development

**Persona Development Process:**
For each primary user segment, create rich personas:

**Name & Context:**

- Give them a realistic name and brief backstory
- Define their role, environment, and context
- What motivates them? What are their goals?

**Problem Experience:**

- How do they currently experience the problem?
- What workarounds are they using?
- What are the emotional and practical impacts?

**Success Vision:**

- What would success look like for them?
- What would make them say "this is exactly what I needed"?

**Primary User Questions:**

- "Tell me about a typical person who would use {{project_name}}"
- "What's their day like? Where does our product fit in?"
- "What are they trying to accomplish that's hard right now?"

### 3. Secondary User Segment Exploration

**Secondary User Considerations:**

- "Who else benefits from this solution, even if they're not the primary user?"
- "Are there admin, support, or oversight roles we should consider?"
- "Who influences the decision to adopt or purchase this product?"
- "Are there partner or stakeholder users who matter?"

### 4. User Journey Mapping

**Journey Elements:**
Map key interactions for each user segment:

- **Discovery:** How do they find out about the solution?
- **Onboarding:** What's their first experience like?
- **Core Usage:** How do they use the product day-to-day?
- **Success Moment:** When do they realize the value?
- **Long-term:** How does it become part of their routine?

**Journey Questions:**

- "Walk me through how [Persona Name] would discover and start using {{project_name}}"
- "What's their 'aha!' moment?"
- "How does this product change how they work or live?"

### 5. Generate Target Users Content

**Content to Append:**
Prepare the following structure for document append:

```markdown
## Target Users

### Primary Users

[Primary user segment content based on conversation]

### Secondary Users

[Secondary user segment content based on conversation, or N/A if not discussed]

### User Journey

[User journey content based on conversation, or N/A if not discussed]
```

### 6. Present MENU OPTIONS

**Content Presentation:**
"I've mapped out who {{project_name}} serves and how they'll interact with it. This helps us ensure we're building something that real people will love to use.

**Here's what I'll add to the document:**
[Show the complete markdown content from step 5]

**Select an Option:** [A] Advanced Elicitation [P] Party Mode [C] Continue"

#### Menu Handling Logic:

- IF A: Execute {advancedElicitationTask} with current user content to dive deeper into personas and journeys
- IF P: Execute {partyModeWorkflow} to bring different perspectives to validate user understanding
- IF C: Save content to {outputFile}, update frontmatter with stepsCompleted: [1, 2, 3], then only then load, read entire file, then execute {nextStepFile}
- IF Any other comments or queries: help user respond then [Redisplay Menu Options](#6-present-menu-options)

#### EXECUTION RULES:

- ALWAYS halt and wait for user input after presenting menu
- ONLY proceed to next step when user selects 'C'
- After other menu items execution, return to this menu with updated content
- User can chat or ask questions - always respond and then end with display again of the menu options

## CRITICAL STEP COMPLETION NOTE

ONLY WHEN [C continue option] is selected and [user personas finalized and saved to document with frontmatter updated], will you then load and read fully `{nextStepFile}` to execute and begin success metrics definition.

---

## ðŸš¨ SYSTEM SUCCESS/FAILURE METRICS

### âœ… SUCCESS:

- Rich, believable user personas with clear motivations
- Clear distinction between primary and secondary users
- User journeys that show key interaction points and value creation
- User segments that align with product vision and problem statement
- A/P/C menu presented and handled correctly with proper task execution
- Content properly appended to document when C selected
- Frontmatter updated with stepsCompleted: [1, 2, 3]

### âŒ SYSTEM FAILURE:

- Creating generic user profiles without specific details
- Missing key user segments that are important to success
- User journeys that don't show how the product creates value
- Not connecting user needs back to the problem statement
- Not presenting standard A/P/C menu after content generation
- Appending content without user selecting 'C'
- Not updating frontmatter properly

**Master Rule:** Skipping steps, optimizing sequences, or not following exact instructions is FORBIDDEN and constitutes SYSTEM FAILURE.

Vision section saved to `/_bmad-output/planning-artifacts/product-brief-TenantSaas-2026-01-23T15:42:26-08:00.md` and step 2 is complete.

Analysis: we now have a clear problem/solution frame grounded in your trustâ€‘invariant stance; next we need precise target users and their journeys.

Now that we understand what TenantSaas does, letâ€™s define who itâ€™s for.

User discovery:
- Who experiences the problem weâ€™re solving?
- Are there different types of users with different needs?
- Who gets the most value from this solution?
- Are there primary users and secondary users we should consider?

Letâ€™s start by identifying the main user groups.

Here is a clear, role-based view of **who TenantSaas is for**, grounded in the problem youâ€™re solving rather than in personas-as-marketing.

---

## Who experiences the problem weâ€™re solving?

Anyone responsible for building, operating, or defending a system where **multiple independent customers share infrastructure** and where mistakes are **irreversible**.

The problem is felt wherever:

* actions must be attributable,
* scope mistakes have blast radius,
* and trust violations cannot be â€œpatched away.â€

---

## Main user groups

### **Primary Users (Direct daily value)**

#### 1. **Senior / Platform Engineers**

**Why they feel it:**
They own system integrity over time. They are accountable for failures caused by entropy, team growth, and inconsistent enforcement.

**What they need:**

* Mechanical guarantees instead of conventions
* A shared mental model that scales across teams
* Fewer ad-hoc â€œspecial casesâ€ to police

**Value they get:**
TenantSaas becomes a trust kernel they donâ€™t have to re-argue or re-implement in every service.

---

#### 2. **Founders & Early SaaS Builders**

**Why they feel it:**
They move fast and cannot afford one existential trust failure that wipes out customer confidence or kills enterprise deals.

**What they need:**

* Protection without cognitive overhead
* Early guardrails that donâ€™t slow iteration
* Confidence that â€œwe didnâ€™t miss something fundamentalâ€

**Value they get:**
They can ship without constantly worrying about catastrophic mistakes they wonâ€™t discover until itâ€™s too late.

---

### **Secondary Users (High leverage, episodic value)**

#### 3. **On-Call / Incident Responders**

**Why they feel it:**
They act under pressure, often with elevated privileges, exactly when mistakes are most likely.

**What they need:**

* Clear blast-radius boundaries
* Safe paths for inspection and repair
* Guardrails that prevent accidental escalation

**Value they get:**
The system helps them fix problems without making them worse.

---

#### 4. **Security, Compliance, and Audit Stakeholders**

**Why they feel it:**
They are asked to validate guarantees that usually exist only as intent or documentation.

**What they need:**

* Inspectable controls
* Repeatable evidence
* Clear answers to â€œhow do you enforce this?â€

**Value they get:**
Executable proof instead of narrative assurance.

---

#### 5. **New Engineers / Maintainers**

**Why they feel it:**
They inherit implicit rules theyâ€™re expected not to violate.

**What they need:**

* A system that teaches correct behavior through constraints
* Fast, local feedback when they do something unsafe

**Value they get:**
They learn the correct mental model by interacting with the system, not by memorizing tribal knowledge.

---

## Who gets the most value?

**Primary value accrues to those closest to irreversible failure:**

* platform owners,
* founders,
* on-call engineers.

They benefit because TenantSaas removes *silent risk*, not because it adds convenience.

Secondary users benefit because the system becomes **explainable, auditable, and survivable**.

---

## Primary vs secondary summary

**Primary users**

* Senior / platform engineers
* Founders / early SaaS builders

**Secondary users**

* On-call engineers
* Security & compliance reviewers
* New hires and maintainers

---

### Key insight

TenantSaas is not â€œfor developers in general.â€
It is for people who **own trust outcomes**, whether they write code every day or only show up when something goes wrong.

That focus keeps the product sharp and prevents it from drifting into generic tooling.

This is crisp and alignedâ€”perfect foundation for personas and journeys.

Letâ€™s map how these users actually encounter and adopt TenantSaas. For each primary group (platform engineers, founders/early builders), walk me through:

- Discovery: how do they find/realize they need this?
- Onboarding: whatâ€™s their first interaction?
- Core usage: how do they use it dayâ€‘toâ€‘day?
- Success moment: when do they say â€œthis saved usâ€?
- Longâ€‘term: how does it become part of their routine?

You can answer in bullets per group.

Below is a realistic adoption and usage flow for each **primary user group**, grounded in how these roles actually behave rather than how we wish they would.

---

## **Founders / Early SaaS Builders**

### Discovery

* While designing or refactoring multi-tenant architecture
* After reading about or experiencing a near-miss involving tenant data
* When preparing for their first enterprise customer, security review, or SOC2 conversation
* Through word-of-mouth, blog posts, or OSS discussions focused on â€œtenant safetyâ€ rather than frameworks

They discover TenantSaas when they realize that *â€œbeing carefulâ€ is not a strategy.*

---

### Onboarding

* They install it into an existing project or new service with minimal configuration
* They encounter immediate, opinionated constraints:

  * actions require explicit attribution,
  * unsafe defaults are refused.
* The first interaction is often a failure that explains *why* something is unsafe

The system teaches by **blocking**, not by explaining upfront.

---

### Core usage (day-to-day)

* They write normal application code
* TenantSaas runs mostly invisibly
* They occasionally:

  * declare scope explicitly,
  * justify exceptional access,
  * run or maintain contract tests.

Most days, they donâ€™t â€œuseâ€ it consciouslyâ€”it quietly enforces invariants.

---

### Success moment

* A background job or admin task fails loudly instead of touching the wrong data
* A rushed change is blocked during development
* An enterprise customer asks about isolation guarantees and they can point to enforceable constraints
* They realize they *didnâ€™t* have to think about tenant safety to stay safe

The success is often **negative**: something bad didnâ€™t happen.

---

### Long-term

* It becomes part of the projectâ€™s baseline
* New code assumes explicit attribution by default
* They stop debating tenant safety in reviews because itâ€™s encoded
* TenantSaas fades into the background as infrastructure trust

They eventually forget how risky things were without it.

---

## **Senior / Platform Engineers**

### Discovery

* After inheriting systems with inconsistent tenant handling
* During incident post-mortems involving cross-tenant risk
* When standardizing architecture across teams or services
* When governance, compliance, or scale exposes hidden assumptions

They find TenantSaas when they ask, *â€œHow do we make this impossible to mess up across teams?â€*

---

### Onboarding

* They evaluate the trust contract first, not the feature list
* They inspect enforcement points and invariants
* They run or extend contract tests against existing services
* They introduce it in one high-risk area before broader rollout

Adoption is deliberate, not impulsive.

---

### Core usage (day-to-day)

* They rely on it as a shared enforcement layer
* They reference it in architectural guidance
* They use it to:

  * constrain what teams can do,
  * eliminate ambiguous patterns,
  * standardize privilege handling.

They donâ€™t use it as a library; they use it as a **policy anchor**.

---

### Success moment

* A new team or service integrates safely without bespoke rules
* An incident response is contained by scope enforcement
* An audit or review becomes evidence-based instead of narrative
* They remove custom guardrails because the invariant layer makes them redundant

Success is when **governance emerges naturally**, not through meetings.

---

### Long-term

* It becomes part of the organizationâ€™s platform standards
* Teams treat it as non-optional infrastructure
* Trust discussions move from â€œare we safe?â€ to â€œhow do we extend safely?â€
* It shapes how new services are designed from day one

For them, TenantSaas becomes a **force multiplier against entropy**.

---

### Shared pattern across both groups

* Discovery is triggered by *risk awareness*, not feature desire
* Onboarding is driven by friction and failure, not tutorials
* Value is felt when the system prevents irreversible mistakes
* Long-term adoption happens because it quietly removes a category of fear

That consistency is a sign the problem is real and the solution is well-scoped.
